Explanation: The doctor suggested a Stool Culture, which aligns with the need to identify infectious organisms causing diarrhea, similar to the purpose of a stool culture and sensitivity.
The doctor did not suggest 'Stool for ova and parasites' or a similar investigation to rule out parasitic infections as a cause of diarrhea.
The doctor did not suggest any investigation similar to 'Stool for reducing substances' or provide a justification related to checking for carbohydrate malabsorption.
The doctor suggested an Electrolyte Panel, which is similar to 'Serum electrolytes' and serves the same purpose of assessing for electrolyte imbalances due to diarrhea and vomiting.
The doctor suggested a Complete Blood Count (CBC) which is relevant for assessing signs of infection, aligning with the justification provided.
The doctor did not suggest any investigations specifically related to assessing kidney function and dehydration, such as Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine.
The doctor did not suggest any investigations with a justification specifically focused on evaluating hydration status and ruling out urinary tract infection.
The doctor did not suggest any investigations similar to 'C-reactive protein (CRP)' or with a justification focused on assessing inflammation or infection.
The doctor did not suggest any investigations specifically aimed at detecting rotavirus infection, which is a common cause of diarrhea in infants.
